body.p:
Frankfort Ky May 30th 1863.
To His Excellency J. F. Robinson
Governor of Kentucky

I have today been informed by Maj. Luckett that you wished in writing the Substance of the statements made by Rev. Mr Stevenson and myself at our interview with you about the 1st of March last in regard to Philips, a convict in the Ky Penitentiary. I therefore with much pleasure communicate ^to^ you in writing, Substantially what I said on that occasion, viz. That I have been acquainted with said Philips four or five years, This acquaintance was formed by my being thrown among the convicts in a business and ministerial character capacity, During this acquaintance I have found him a man of good deportment in every respect. A feeling of sympathy having been thus awak^en^ed in my mind in his behalf, I was led to inquire into his history. I learned from the officers of the Prison, that his conduct Since he had been there, had been unexceptionable. I learned too that his character prior to this offence had been good. In my personal interviews with the Prisoner he frankly confessed the crime, and the justice of his sentence. His only ground of hope was that in your clemency as the Executive of the laws of the Commonwealth, your Honor would adjudge that he had paid the penalty of violated law. And could
therefore be restored to the freedom and to honorable standing. From what I know of the matter I drawn the following conclusions. viz
First. That beyond a doubt Philips was guilty of the offence charged against him. But
Second. That it was his first offence, he in a State of intoxication, being made the root of experienced villains, while they escaped the punishment due to their crimes.

Third. That his previous character being good, and his conduct Since his imprisonment, having been commendable, and his having already for Several years Suffered the penalty of his offence, the majesty of the law has been vindicated, the ends of public justice fully met, and the life of the prisoner reformed, And that where these ends have been attained mercy should come to his relief.

Fourth. That the Prisoner having a refined and pious wife, who seems devoted to him even in his degradation, it would be an act of humanity, and a source of inexpressible joy to her if he could be restored to his family.

With great respect
Your obdt Servant
J. B. Tharp
